Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket as I stand outside the synagogue, the evening air cool against my skin. It’s my mother, calling for our usual Sunday check-in. I know she’s waiting to hear about my week, to share her stories, to feel that I’m still close even though I live miles away. I promised her I’d call at this time, every week, no matter what. But inside, the rabbi is searching the street, his eyes landing on me. They need one more for the minyan, just one more to say Kaddish for a grieving family. I can see the mourners, their faces drawn with sorrow, waiting for the prayer that can only happen if I step inside. My mother’s ringtone keeps playing, insistent and familiar, tugging me toward my family’s expectations. But my community needs me too, just for a few minutes, to fulfill a sacred obligation. I stand frozen, phone in hand, heart pounding, torn between the voice of my mother and the call of my faith.
